values:
Fun quote:
"Follow your heart – but take your brain with you."

http://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/05/science/cern-physicists-may-have-discovered-higgs-boson-particle.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all
"
So far, the physicists admit, they know little. The CERN results are mostly based on measurements of two or three of the dozen different ways, or “channels,” by which a Higgs boson could be produced and then decay.

There are hints, but only hints so far, that some of the channels are overproducing the Higgs while others might be underproducing, clues maybe that there is more than the Standard Model at work.

“This could be the first in a ring of discoveries,” Dr. Tonelli said.

CERN will be examining the rest of the channels over the coming months and years, and the idea that the Standard Model could be cracking is a prospect that physicists find thrilling. Only time, and a few more trillion proton collisions, will tell.

In an e-mail, Maria Spiropulu, a professor at the California Institute of Technology who works with the CMS team at CERN, wrote about the Higgs: “I personally do not want it to be standard model anything — I don’t want it to be simple or symmetric or as predicted. I want us all to have been dealt a complex hand that will send me (and all of us) in a (good) loop for a long time.”
"
(emphasis mine)

I've italicized what I think are the most important lines in the piece. Well, the science-y stuff is way important, too ... But these italicized lines are examples of the attitude that seems to be prevalent in the scientific community. This is a big part of my answer to the folks who like to say that evolution is "only" a "matter of belief". That is, those groups who are trying to tear down scientific theories in the public square, in an attempt to make their own religious belief systems look comparatively better. Equating scientific theories to religious belief systems is silly. In my mind, the main difference is that, while many human beings have a habit of getting very attached to certain ideas or ways of thinking, such attachments are thankfully not the norm in science. I cannot say the same for religious communities. The physicists interviewed in this piece seem to have no particular attachment to the Standard Model they've been working with for decades. It sounds like they, as a group, would rather see it turned on its head. Conversely, religious groups seem to be irrevocably attached to the same old clusters of ideas. Instead of adjusting their understanding of the universe as new evidence comes to light, they seem to come up with rationalization after rationalization to justify the beliefs they already hold. Like this: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ad_hoc_hypothesis

I can be convinced to adopt a new idea, or to abandon an old idea, given good evidence, and good arguments. Can you?

A rant-y facebook response, for safekeeping:
---------------------------------------------------------------------
"No matter how powerful and independent they are, women still want to be pursued, protected, and cared for by their partners," psychologist Diana Kirschner, Ph.D.
http://www.womenshealthmag.com/sex-and-relationships/modern-romance?cm_mmc=Facebook-_-WomensHealth-_-Content-Sex-_-ModernRomance

"This totally makes sense to me" ... "YAY" ...

Why do y'all sound like you're celebrating? Is it satisfying, comforting, to have everything so neatly packaged? To have clear answers? Men are this way, women are that way ... yes, yes, we all nod in agreement. Of course, similarities among men as a group, and among women as a group, are pretty easy to find ... if that's what you're looking for, if that's the idea you're attached to. The minute I bought a jeep, I started noticing jeeps everywhere. It's a thing people do. But if you start looking for differences among men, and among women, you'll find plenty of those too.

If y'all got Ph.D.'s after your names, you, too, could make stuff up based on anecdotal evidence and have everyone believe you.
Here's a quote I like a lot better:
"Psychologists  –  including me  –  always have to be looking beyond their own biases. They need to avoid getting so attached to a particular theory or perspective that they go out of their way to protect the theory," Conley said. "Data should be the guide, and you have to look at data in every way you can think of to see if the story you are telling is really the best one."
http://www.livescience.com/16900-busted-gender-myths-bedroom.html

Let's all be critical of the conclusions we're fed.

I've decided I like giving blood. I've always donated with the Red Cross. I do it cause it's necessary, not cause I like it, but anyway, I like it cause they give you juice and cookies after. Feels like kindergarten. The only other thing I need is some sleeping mats to build into a fort, so I can eat my cookies in a fort. Plus, I'm required to sit and snack for a few minutes. How awesome is that? It's like Savasana in yoga, only with a big basket of cookies.

I recently donated plasma with this company that pays you (supposedly for your time, not for the plasma), and the whole thing didn't feel right. Once you're done, they kick you out of your chair and send you on your way. They won't even give you a band-aid unless you ask for one. And those little finger-sized band-aids for when they prick your finger? Ya, they don't have those. The Red Cross has me spoiled. I know it's not as necessary if you're just donating plasma, but come on, people! Can I get some freakin cookies?!

So over winter break, around 5pm one day, I was walking around downtown LA with Melissa Chavez and her picture-taking entourage. We passed this grungy-looking guy shouting about god ... and he had an AMAZINGLY loud voice. No mike, no bullhorn, just a dude you could hear preaching, over the traffic, from like 40 yards away. I wish he'd use that voice for something else. 

It got me thinking about the question that is sometimes posed, by preachy folks who want to give an audience pause: If Jesus had appeared to deliver his message in modern times, would anybody listen? The implied answer is no. Because, of course, he would likely appear as one of the lowest of our society, and when the down-and-out start talking religion, who listens? We often assume they're crazy ... and we're often right. 

But if I may pretend to be a believer for a moment, my answer to the question would be yes, folks would listen. Not everybody, but many. That's because, if the stories in the Bible are any indication, Jesus would not only rise from humble beginnings, just to test our habit of judging books by their covers. He would also be infused with godly charisma, wisdom, and intellect. The guy does have a message to deliver, right? Folks might initially be dismissive, as is our habit, but a good number would start to think, hey - this isn't just some schizophrenic transient, screaming about redemption on a street corner. This guy's different. Articulate. No disconnect from reality evident. And he's got all these fun fables ... 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In other news, weather.com sez it's going to be negative 17 degrees fahrenheit tonight. I'm about ready to start praying for sun ... oh, wait, that never works, does it?

Twenty minutes ago I was at the laundromat. A guy leaves his bike outside, walks in and wants to chat. He's a bit off, somewhat unkept, could be homeless.

He rambles, in between puffs on his cig. Talks about anything and everything.

Eventually, he says: "So what's your gig, man?"
"I'm in law school. Downtown, St. Thomas."
"Oh, law school, I know what that is."
"So what's your gig?"
"I'm a starship captain."

Oh yeah, he was serious. It got better from there.

He took off after a bit, rode his bike into the night. Duty calls.

It makes sense to me that a government and its policies can often be measured by the quality of life of the majority of its citizens. However, quality of life does not only have to do with access to food, shelter, clean water, and the other "basics" necessary to sustain life. It also involves freedom, self-actualization, all that good stuff. 
So, charitable social programs: sometimes their right-wing critics have a point. When we gain yet another safety net, what do we lose?

Sincerely,

When I was in first grade, there was a mirror hanging near the classroom door, at first-grader head level. Around the border of the mirror, it said something like, "This person is special." I suppose the folks who study these things have found that there may be some psychological benefit to telling kids they're special. If I remember right, and I may not remember right, that mirror didn't make sense in my little first-grader mind, and I may have even been a tad annoyed. 'Why are they telling me I'm special?,' I might have thought ... 'There's a ton of first graders here, and lots of people of all ages all over the place, so what the heck makes me special? What makes anybody special? If everybody's different from everybody else, then isn't everybody also the same, in that way?' Well, maybe I didn't think that exactly, but I may have had some inkling along those lines. Luckily, I'm not in first grade anymore, and I don't need anybody to make me feel special. I don't feel the need to be special, and I don't think I ever did.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

So this hot chick at work is telling me to come out with everybody that night, they're going drinking at the Dave & Buster's across the street, and I'm getting her number so I can have someone to call to find everybody when I get there, and I start typing her name into my phone and I ask for her last name and she's like, "Duuumb", and she's complaining that I shouldn't put her last name in my phone, cause she's the only Debnye in the office, and when am I gonna meet any other "Debnye"s, and I'm just saying that it helps me remember people's names, and I like all my contacts in the same format, and she doesn't like that idea, that they're all the same and she wants to be special in my phone, and I then remember her last name anyway, so I type it in, and she's all whiny like, "why can't I be special?!"

Me:
"What is it with women and wanting to be special?!
You're not special, nobody's special!
Get over yourself!
Gimme your number."


I think I've got myself a new pick-up line ... they say being an asshole gets you chicks, right?

Story of the day: 

After she testified incoherently at her Social Security Disability hearing, the judge kindly granted the claimant a continuance. 

"Err, counsel, your client seems to be having an... interaction with her medications. I think we'd better continue this hearing...?" 

"Yes, I think we'd better, your honor." 

In the hall outside the hearing room, our representative tried to explain to his glassy-eyed client what had just happened. One of her brief periods of cognizance spurred her to belt out the following brilliant line, which has to be one of the best lines ever uttered by a drunk at one of the least opportune moments: 

"These fucking pills don't work without the alcohol!" 

We're thinking of making a t-shirt.

My dad likes to tell this story:

When I was little, on one particular Christmas, I was playing with a present I'd got, like one does, and my dad asked me, "who got that for you? Did Mommy and Daddy buy it or did Santa bring it?" I'm sure you can guess the age at which a question like that would make sense. Anyway, I announced, "Mommy and Daddy buyed it!"
My Dad said, "Well, big people say bought it. Mommy and Daddy bought it."
"And little people say buyed it!"

Cause I fuckin said so. What, you got a problem?

I just bought gas at an Arco on Harbor Blvd., half a block north of the 22 fwy, for $2.61. Fuck Yeah. That's what I'm talking about. Ever since America's gas prices started going all wonky-like, I've been saying, based on my guesstimation of how gas prices should have steadily increased over the last 7 or 8 years, that gas should cost around $2.60 per gallon. I'm totally comfortable with that price, and with a steady increase in price consistent with the general cost of living. Never mind that it's around $7 per gallon in Ireland (translated into U.S. terms), and over $9 in Eritrea. Oh yeah, and pennies per gallon in Venezuela and Saudi Arabia. Fuckers. Gas prices often vary based on government policy, I'm told. Some countries tax the hell out of gasoline, and the price goes through the roof.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Prop 8 is an insanity, born entirely of ignorance and fear. Let freedom ring.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

El fin.

"Don't say another goddamn word. Up until now, I've been polite. If you say anything else - word one - I will kill myself. And when my tainted spirit finds its destination, I will topple the master of that dark place.

From my black throne, I will lash together a machine of bone and blood, and fueled by my hatred for you this fear engine will bore a hole between this world and that one.

When it begins, you will hear the sound of children screaming - as though from a great distance. A smoking orb of nothing will grow above your bed, and from it will emerge a thousand starving crows. As I slip through the widening maw in my new form, you will catch only a glimpse of my radiance before you are incinerated. Then, as tears of bubbling pitch stream down my face, my dark work will begin...

I will open one of my six mouths, and I will sing the song that ends the earth."


I like that little speech.

It's from a comic I was just told about (pray excuse my ignorance):

 http://www.penny-arcade.com/comic/2006/4/10/

On the front of this past Friday's LA Times was a big picture of Barack Obama. I know it's been said, but it struck me this time-- he's very light-skinned for a black guy. Of course, he has to be... if his skin was darker, he wouldn't have a chance, not now, not in this country. He'd look way too much like a "foreigner". As it is, I think he's got a good shot. Dubya has got everyone sick and tired of old white men. 

It was mentioned, I think, by most of our history teachers that a sign of the racism of the times (America's southeast, maybe a century ago?) was the tendency of folks to call a person "black" if they looked to be tainted by even a tiny bit of black ancestry. If we were to reverse that attitude, wouldn't Obama be considered white? We know he has "white" in him... Would celebrating him as (maybe) the first black president, while a leap forward in some ways, actually be a troubling sign of racist tendencies still alive and well in our culture's collective psyche? Well, I think the answer is apparent. I wasn't about to seriously question his assignment to the "black" category, were you?

I'm going to need a roommate to help me rent a place come February... I'm thinking somewhere in the Garden Grove area, or Cypress, or one of those cities around there. I'm not too picky. Travel times to places I need to be regularly, from Garden Grove, according to Google maps: 15 mins, 25 mins, 18 mins... maybe 40 mins or an hour if I'm feeling like a road trip... y'know, once in a rare while... amazing. I have a feeling, though, that if I do move out there, I still won't save any gas. I'll likely find distant places to drive myself to.

I like to party, but I'm not very good at throwing parties. I just like an active house, having people over, sex drugs and rock n' roll, etc. Noise and late nights are a plus, and though I usually won't cause them, I'll gladly participate if they happen. Of course, quiet is fine and dandy, too. 

I'm rarely home. I probably won't sleep at home a couple nights out of any given week.

I'm generally neat and clean, but I'm not psycho about it. If something / some area is a little dirty, I'll clean it eventually, when it starts to bug me. If you (hypothetical roommate) need to live in a spotless home, you might end up doing most of the cleaning. However, if you like to let dishes overflow the sink, spiderwebs take over light fixtures, and greasy crumby nastiness cover kitchen countertops, then I might end up getting to most of the cleaning before you do, and you would thus not be my ideal roommate. If you can let things get a little dirty or messy once in a while in a comfy "lived-in" sort of way, but will also clean somewhat regularly, then you and I might get along.

I'm financially stable.

I'm not a fan of pets with hair, sheddings, or droppings of any sort. Unless they're in a cage or somehow kept away from my furniture / carpet. Although I might tolerate a pet if it's really super cute... 

I like me some METAL. (I needed to throw in something manly-sounding after that last one...)

Male or female roommates would be fine.

I'm looking to pay $400 or $500 per month for my own room, so splitting a two-, or even better, a three-bedroom would be good. I know I might have to settle for higher rent than that, but $500 or less per month is my goal.

I'm a Costco whore. 

I dunno what else to mention.

If you are reading this, it is your job to find me a cool roommate or two. Get to it.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In other news... 

I was recently asked, "so, are you guys 'official' yet?" 

As truly awed as I am at her existence, my answer stayed the same as it has been to such inquiries in years past: "I don't really do 'official'." 

We are two people who like to spend lots of time together and do yucky things like kiss, hold hands, and swap cooties. Simple as that. There is no "official" in my mind. There is nothing added or expected. There is no social category that we fall into. When we need a term to describe ourselves, "dating" will suffuce. 

Why don't I do 'official'? I'm tempted to rant. But I'm tired.

A few weeks back we took our first successful midday nap together. We needed to crash a bit before executing our evening plans. This is notable because, previous to this nap, we could not successfully sleep in a bed together without, umm... distracting each other.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I really need to drink more. I miss beer.

My favorite quote of the night, which I am likely misquoting: "Magic wants to make you think it's real. Sideshow makes you wish to hell it wasn't." (-- a glass-eating member of "The Freakshow Deluxe", performing at the Magic Castle)

Just got back from Vegas. Visited friends, hung out, bought fireworks, bowled, played blackjack... 

...wait..."bought fireworks"...? 

I have FIREWORKS! 
HEEEEE! :D 

I refused to make the same mistake I made two years ago. Back then (June 2005?) I was on my way with Justin Knox in my car to help move Tim back from Wyoming. I pulled into a gas station off the 15 just north of Vegas, and me and Justin saw a lovely sign painted on the wall of the gas station shop: "Liquor-cigarettes-food-FIREWORKS..." 

"Dood! ...EXPLOSIVES!" 

I didn't have much money then, so I got a few cool items, including some random stuff I wasn't familiar with, but it looked fun. Then that 4th of July, I used it all, and I really wish I'd got more, cause some of it was really cool, and I had only bought like one of each item. So this time around, I made sure to grab at least TWO of everything I wanted. $98 worth of wondrous explosives. Ice cream made it $100. 

For the first time in my life, I have ROMAN CANDLES! Like, TEN of them! And holy shit I bought some giant rockets that were like $5 PER SHELL. Plus a shitload of tiny bottle rockets, little firecrackers, and other random goodies. And the ones I REALLY wanted I got three of... these little cardboard boats. You float them in water, you light them, they jet across the water and shoot stuff... not all that spectacular, but WAY fun... Those are my favorite. 

The shop was on Indian land, by the way... the Moapa Paiute reservation. Not a bad plan, that... the government gives you the crappiest middle-of-nowhere parcel of land they can find, and what do you do? Set up shop by the freeway and sell some wonderful illegal shit. Go them.  

-------------------------------------------------------------------

At work recently, I read a handwritten letter from a client who wanted to tell his story... it included a quick rant about how he had moved to Vegas and then moved away, as he couldn't stand the place... it was "devoid of culture", he said. One thing that always strikes me about Vegas when I go there: I'll be walking through a casino, at any imaginable hour of the day or night, and I'll see folks sitting at the slot machines, poking away at the screens. They're often older, and they all look sad, tired, or bored. Doggedly chasing a dream, maybe? It's always such a sad sight to me. Now, I can't rightly guess what's going on in their heads. I might look sad or bored while I'm playing chess, for example, but behind my face my mind is working and I'm having a good ol' time. I dunno how you can get that same effect from a slot machine, but to each his own. I'm usually not too excited about gambling, but sometimes I prefer games of chance that involve a little more judgment and skill... like cards. There's money to be made in Vegas but not through some one-in-a-million jackpot. It's at the smaller-time games, where you can win a little here and there, where you can peck away at the house's takings. My friend told me something about gambling once that made perfect sense, but that had never occurred to me: pick a roulette table or a card game or any such thing where similar rules of chance might apply, and watch for a bit. Wait 'till the roulette table starts going one color, over and over. Or wait 'till the dealer starts to win. Then wait for the luck to turn. Jump in right then. Ride lady luck 'till she's sore. When the luck starts to turn again, get out. I won five dollars that way, but only by accident. If I'd trusted myself, I would've won ten. Blackjack would've paid for pizza either way. Not a bad deal.

When I try to tell someone something in writing, I write way too much. But I have to fully explain the thought, you know? So I dunno how to write less without possibly sounding retarded... 

Enneyweys, this guy organized a swing workshop, and asked me to teach, and I said yeah, cool, and then suddenly I get a flyer with all the workshop info on it, and I was like, hmmm... I really wish I had had some input in the planning process... and I ended up sending him the below email just now, and I figured I'd store the email here for my reference in case anyone else asks me to help with their workshop in the future... plus cause it's so damn long I didn't wanna just delete it... 

---------------------------------------------------------------

Thanks for the two-hour Big Apple slot btw... good idea. 

Do you have many sign-ups yet? Any idea how many people will show? 

Questions: to start off the Big Apple lesson, I'd like to show the students the whole routine on video. The original "Keep Punchin" clip is only a couple of minutes. It takes a group to do it, obviously, so me and Natalia can't demonstrate its awesomeness all by ourselves. I figure we'll try and plug in a laptop and have the video downloaded already, just so the students can see what they're going for... I assume there's no internet access there...? But there will be enough outlets for both the speakers/sound system and a laptop, right? Should I bring an extension cord? And I can just bring CDs to teach to, right? Are you familiar with the equipment at this place? If people dance near the sound system, will it make the CD skip? Does the sound system play almost anything, or will it reject my burned CDs? (I know these are stupid questions, but I gotta make sure...) 


Finally... 
I know, as I'm sure you do, that when you're in charge of something, everyone wants to give you their opinion on how they think things should be done. Well, here's mine (feel free to file it away with all the other crackpot opinions in the suggestion box): I would have charged less. Maybe the cost of renting the space drove the price up, I don't know, but I do know that $15 per hour-long group class is about the most expensive class you'll find in the SoCal swing community. Sure, there are others that charge the same price, but I'm not them. I don't have the teaching or dancing experience of Doug Silton, Peter Loggins, Shesha Marvin, Nick Williams, Jofflyn Valencia, Jeremy Otth, or whoever else is teaching around here nowadays. In fact, I think Jofflyn frequently charges less for his group lessons, and many other group swing lessons are less, too. So, in the case of this workshop, there are lots of more experienced swing dancers and swing teachers than I who are underselling me. I don't feel that people should be paying more to learn from me than they pay to learn from all those guys above. I would have leant towards maybe $35 or $40 for the whole day, and maybe $12 per individual class. And I'm aware, of course, that if you charge too little, many people won't value what you're offering as much... so there's a balance to be found. Anyway, there's not much to be done with my suggestions at this point. All we can do now is try our best to deliver what we've advertised. Which means I need to make sure to lead some really kick-ass lessons, to make them worth people's money. 

Just curious: did you ask Lupita to teach? Maybe she's a little burnt out on teaching swing nowadays, or not, I dunno. Did you ask Allen and Miki? Morgan? These are some of the people who taught me to dance. And what about Christian? Shane? James? They're all right there at Coffee Depot most weeks, easily accessible. I wouldn't mind learning stuff from them. (I'd learn from Sean, too, so I'm glad you grabbed him.) If I was you I'd try to recruit some of them for the next workshop, maybe, if they're down. I think you made a good choice asking me and Natalia to teach the Big Apple-- we probably know it better than most Coffee Depot attendees... but for Balboa, for example, I would have asked Lupita and Christian, or Brittany Wallace if she's around, or maybe Allen and Miki... or hey, why not go all out and ask Sarah Lerner, Nick Williams, Jeremy Otth, or even Peter Loggins or Sylvia Sykes to teach a balboa lesson... maybe they'd say yes, who knows? If you've got the best of the best teaching, then you could easily justify the price of the class... and I know fame doesn't necessarily equal good teaching, but experience often does. When looking for teachers, I'd shoot for the people who have been teaching and dancing forever. And besides the big names, there's many amazing swing dancers and teachers that keep a lower profile... Find them online or at swing clubs, and say, hey, I don't know you but I think you rock and I'm doing this workshop and it was pretty successful last time and you should teach... something like that. I'd love to help you recruit teachers next time if you want me to, btw... 

So anyways, thanks for reading all that, and most of all thanks for bringing swing to the high desert, however you do it. I know all of the above isn't good feedback, but some feedback is better than none, I figure, so there you go. And this is only one person's opinion, of course, so do your thing and take it for what it's worth. 

Love, peace, and hippie grease, 

Aidan 

-------------------------------------------------
< / entry >

Yesterday, I came home from work, and I wanted munchies. I had a glass of Guinness, a peanut butter and honey sammich, jello, and chips with Fritos bean dip. It was the best thing ever. Then I ran later. Good way to spend an evening.

I've been playing this computer game called Cyberstorm. It's a turn-based, army-of-robots vs army-of-robots, Windows-98 kind of game that I used to play in high school. Which means Windows XP didn't want to install it, but fuck Windows XP. So now I'm playing it a lot, and it's WAY easier than it was in high school. Conclusion? I think I'm smarter now than I was in high school. Which is amazing cause 1) I was a smart cookie in high school and 2) I really thought I'd been getting dumber since. So yeah. I rule. At old turn-based sci-fi strategy games.

I went on a cruise with Liz and her family recently. Late one night, we were wandering the ship after most everything had shut down. We went up on the "observation deck" to watch the night go by. It's a big open deck at the front of the ship, about nine levels up (out of eleven). There's lots of lounge chairs in tight rows across the deck. So we walk up the stairs, cross the deck, and lean on the front railing. Liz says, "Is there something weird going on to your left?" I look and there is. I see a girl with long hair, bent over between the lounge chairs, smoking pole like a pro. Can't really see the guy lying below her. We figure we'll give them some privacy, so we turn to go. As we approach the stairs to exit, a small group of teenagers come up the stairs. Cause you know-- wandering the ship at night is the cool thing to do when you're in high school. Wait--but, we... also... yeah. Anyways, I'm thinking, should I warn them? Ehhh... Nope. So the kids take a few steps onto the deck, and me and Liz turn to watch their reactions... a gasp, a giggle, a loud whisper of "Oh my GAWD!" with the little girls covering their open mouths... Oh, drop the act, little ladies, you know what you did after the homecoming dance... anyways, it was funny. And kind of depressing. I wanted a blow job, too...

Comment and I'll:
1 - Tell you why I friended you. (If you're on my f-list, that is.)
2 - Associate you with something - fandom, a song, a colour, a photo, a sexual position, etc. (Or, not) 
3 - Tell you something I like about you.
4 - Tell you a memory I have of you.
5 - Associate you with a character/pairing.
6 - Ask something I've always wanted to know about you.
7 - Tell you my favorite user pic of yours.
8 - In return, you must post this in your LJ.

Why do my bowling scores always make the news in Aidanland? 149. I rawk. 


I was told at work today that there's this restaurant called "The Warehouse" in Marina Del Rey, and that it would be a cool place to take a date: www.mdrwarehouse.com

Maybe I'm not doing too bad after all.

A girl used the word "diphthong" in conversation, while we were dancing on Monday night. It was way hot.

Pick a soccer field or a football field, and jog along the side longways. When you reach the corner, turn around and sprint the diagonal to the opposite corner. Turn again and jog the long side of the field. If you're tired, you can jog as slow as you'd like. Just make sure it's actually a jog. Hit the corner, turn, and sprint the other diagonal. Keep this going as long as you want. Twenty minutes, thirty... more? You will have sprinted an "X" across the field's center. That's why it's called "running 'x's". Maybe, on a given occasion, it's morning, and maybe there's dew on the grass. If you can look at the field from higher ground, you can inspect your work. You'll see the lines where your footsteps have cut through the dew's shine. Heavier lines, if there's a bunch of guys running with you. 

It's fucking back, baby! HOO-AHH! 
I'm allowed to claim, I think, that I'm running again. Let's see how long I can keep this going. Yesterday was the first time in a long time that I felt the feeling come back-- the power of it. That's the only word I've got. You're sprinting as hard as you can, over and over, and thinking, "this shit ain't nothin!" It should be hellish, but it's not. You're floating. Kind of like when a Saiyan goes up a power level... wow, sorry, that was bad. I killed it. I'm stopping now.

I've said that I should start memorizing quotes from office space, because they would apply to my everyday work. 


"Excuse me, I believe you have my stapler..." 

"...because they've moved my desk four times already this year, and I used to be over by the window, and I could see the squirrels, and they were married, but then, they switched from the Swingline to the Boston stapler, but I kept my Swingline stapler because it didn't bind up as much, and I kept the staples for the Swingline stapler and it's not okay because if they take my stapler then I'll set the building on fire..." 


Mainly quotes about staplers. And "TPS reports". I write lots of OTR reports. Letters, rather. You don't care what those are. Other kinds of letters too. Sometimes, a Social Security judge likes a letter I write, and somebody who needs money gets money. Usually they ignore the letters. I rarely know one way or the other, though. I found out recently that something I wrote two months ago actually did some good. I happened to come across the same file and saw how things had developed since I'd last handled it. Just a paragraph, nothing involved, but it worked. 

Shit, Office Space makes my job seem all depressing. It's not, really. It's aiite. Fuck Office Space. 

Dood, the ladies at work, they GRUB. Like, in most situations if there's publicly available food, I try to finish it, cause noone else will and if I don't eat it, it'll go to waste. NOT SO here. Our little kitchen in the office is always stocked with candy and cookies and bagels and today we got pizza and that shit was GONE. I think it's awesome. None of this eating-like-a-bird shit that girls do sometimes... 


Side note: Trees are not going extinct because of random people using too many paper towels in public restrooms. We as a society use too much paper because of the idea in business and legal circles that for something to count, it must be "on paper". Like, seriously. Whoa. 

-------------------------------------------------------------

Me and Amy randomly went bowling. Two games. In the first, I bowled a 139, which is damn good for me in general, and fucking spectacular considering that I haven't bowled in forever. Second game, I bowled what was possibly the worst game of my life. My hand got tired. It ached for two days after. Least I beat her, though. Both times. BOO-YAAAA! You bet I gloated. Gentleman, my ass.

US Open was cool. Happened the day after Thanksgiving. The Brigade got fifth place out of six teams. That's not so good, obviously. I would have been ok with fourth place, considering the other performances. Some west coast kids who were, like, twelve or fourteen got fourth. Lame. But they're kids (and they were really good, though, for kids... I was impressed), so whatcha gonna do. 

The thing that killed me was my fucked-up bocker. Everybody, in the course of learning a bocker, or any aerial, has I'm sure thrown lots of shitty ones. I have, too. This particular fuck-up, though, has happened to me like, twice EVER in the year-plus that I've been throwing these things. And those incidents would have been right at the beginning, almost a year ago. Our hands slipped at the end. The bocker itself was perfect, but our fingers slipped away from each other, and we were downstage, stage right, and after that bocker there was supposed to be a pause for a couple of beats. If the routine had kept moving, it wouldn't have been quite so noticeable, but it was VERY noticeable, because we were supposed to be frozen, posed. She was supposed to balance on one foot. The bocker went over, and our hands slipped, and I saw her hop once to keep her balance, in her pose, and I'm thinking "please fuck don't move any more" and then she had to hop back one more time to deal with the momentum of the thing, and that last hop put her just out of my reach. I had to take a step out of formation to catch her hand. Very bad. Then we waltzed again. And in that routine, we were trying to move waltz in a way it wasn't meant to be moved, but that's another discussion. Likely two of the main reasons we didn't place higher, my bocker and the waltz thing... Thank god she landed the bocker, though. Kept her balance. Kudos to her. We found after that her hand had slipped in another lift with a different guy a few seconds beforehand. Both might have been on her, we don't know, don't care, either. 

The team got $200 prize money. $200 for 5th? Damn, we should do the US Open more often... cash money bling bling and all that... and maybe WIN, cause 1st and 2nd prizes are in the $1000 range... 

The great part about the weekend was the lindy room. Being a mainly west-coast swing event, they banished the lindy hoppers to this little room across the hall from the giant ballroom. Three nights in a row, that little room was filled to a comfortable capacity with nothing but pro lindy hoppers, till 4am. It's great when you end up at these kinds of events, especially for afterhours dancing, when only the pros (aka those who have a rabid affinity for swing) show up. You could grab almost any follow in the room and she would be spectacular. Nikki (Shesha Marvin's new wife, tiny, blonde, Shesha runs TJ's, they run the 24 hour dance-a-thon together, she competes nowadays with Mikey Pedroza, the spastic short brown-skinned guy who likes to compete in pro lindy comps...) said "thanks, that was really fun!" after I danced with her. Heeee... "really fun"... She sounded sincere... and pleasantly surprised. I get that a lot lately when dancing with pro follows. They're pleasantly surprised. I think my dancing feels better than it looks, which is preferable to the opposite, I suppose. And my comp fees covered the whole weekend. Schweet. 

--------------------------------------------------

I was reading the list of personality disorders in the medical dictionary at work. I found that a lot of them, in part, described some aspect of my personality. I kind of identified with the descriptions of the following disorders: obsessive-compulsive, avoidant, borderline, paranoid, passive aggressive, and schizoid. Now, I only found things in myself that resembled very minor, slight manifestations of the sorts of attributes associated with these disorders. I'm not crazy, don't worry. I did not, though, identify in any way with the antisocial, histrionic, or narcissistic disorders. Whatever. What my personality resembles or doesn't, what it's composed of, I'm not pondering, in this case. Reading that in the dictionary and laughing at myself was just a passing, entertaining interest at work. What interests me more is why I might have made those associations. See, I usually read horoscopes, personality tests, etc., and roll my eyes. I dismiss them, or at least most of their findings, and I am critical, sometimes overly critical, of their methods and results. Cause ain't nobody gonna package me, sum me up, tell me what I'm about, dammit. Nobody's gonna tell me who I connect with or don't, who I should marry or how I might behave. And that's the weird part. I'm much more open to the suggestion that I'm "out of order" somehow. That I'm weird, different, not quite diagnoseable, but maybe close sometimes. What does that say about me, and how I see myself? Very strange. Which I seem to be ok with. 

--------------------------------------------------

My dad turned 77 today.

Below is a response I wrote a few years ago as a part of a thread on parenting. Well, I started to write it. I do that a lot. I got down some thoughts, but ran out of time, so I saved it to my desktop, and there it waited. Now, I don't remember what I would have added to it, or where the thread was, and I'm sure that thread is long forgotten now anyway, so I'm just gonna post this. You can guess at the content of the post I was responding to. 

-------------------------------------------------------

First, "legal facts"... these are not moral facts. Not realities, just legalities. The results of the current trends of public perception, maybe right, maybe wrong. And that public perception is the problem... this idea of holding the parents responsible for a minor's actions is just one more example of a general trend- a feeling of entitlement when there is gain to be had, and an inclination to pass the buck when responsibility might fall too close to home. I think that feeling of entitlement starts with the way we raise our kids. (By "we" I mean "Americans"- I can't comment on other cultures, I only live here.) Often, we shower them with attention and opportunity, from birth through adolescence- from headphones around mommy's stomach to tons of physical interaction to soccer practice and band practice and yelling at little Billy's teachers when they give him a bad grade. 

Sure, this helps the kids grow up "better adjusted", according to the research... How we define "better adjusted", or course, might need to be adjusted...  

But it also reinforces in kids the idea that they DESERVE all this. Now when these kids grow up, and their kid gets hurt at school, that now-parent DESERVES compensation, and someone's going to pay. 

Now we're trying to legally force parents to watch over their kids 24/7, to make sure the kid doesn't get the parent sued. And so the cycle continues. 

Would you seriously suggest that you should pay the bill for damage that you didn't do? 

And no, nobody had previously mentioned anything about lawsuits in this discussion. The two issues are connected, though, and if one is going to rant about a subject, one might as well consider the subject as a whole, rather than just one example. When people say, "blame the parents!", parents cringe and think of the repo man coming for their new car. That's the way it happens much too often.

Myspace Boons Sexual Activity
A. Harvey for CNN 11/10/06


If you haven't already created a cyber profile on a social networking Web site like MySpace.com or Facebook.com, you're part of a rapidly shrinking minority. People of all ages, parents and children alike, are joining in the recently growing phenomenon.

But what's more phenomenal is the increase of sexual activity among young adults and teenagers. Researchers at the University of California, Berkley show that since the launch of Myspace merely 4 years ago sexual activity among young Americans has skyrocketed nearly 112% percent. Sound for alarm to say the least.

Home to the only place that you will find 15 year old "swingers," Myspace has become the most frugal new addition for teenagers to meet and engage their personal inhibitions and express their affections towards one another.

One 16 year old teen, Jessica Mcbayne, aka "Cynthia C-Cups" has revealing pictures of herself wearing little more than undergarments and even more shocking a picture of herself appearing nude with "scribble marks" etched across her chest and lower regions. When we asked her mother, Trisha McBayne about her daughter's revealing photographs, her mother responded, "I luh my baby! We taking over this (explicative)!" 

Further studies show than nearly 1 in every 3 persons between the age of 14 and 25 who maintain a Myspace account have engaged in a sexual encounter with another account holder. Nearly 80% of that number have engaged in multiple encounters with various Myspace members.

The results are astounding. Whether theses peaks are coincident or not, one thing is certainly non-debatable. Social networks have become more than just places for young adults to post blogs, chat, and share ideas. 

----------------------------------------------------

I think that's awesome. Except for the "mother" mentioned above-- she sounds like a retard. Of course, that quote might be taken out of context. I can't assume much about her or her daughter from this article. In sum, god bless the internet.

A while back, the Brigade had a gig at a rich-looking restaurant for someone's wedding party. By the Queen Mary. Complimentary valet parking. So after the gig, we're waiting and the valets are pulling up lots of nice-looking cars. Then comes mine. It stood out as the loud, dirty one that made funny noises. All squeaky and rumbly. I was so proud.

Y'know how people always yell for bands to play "Free Bird"? The bands always assume the people are joking. Well, they are, mostly. But, overplayed or not, Free Bird is still a badass song. I say next time some heckler yells for Free Bird, the band should just play the damn thing. Rock that shit out. Why not? 

----------------------------------------------------- 

I've been getting more bold of late. Instead of moving all the papers off my desk before I eat something, and being all cautious about it, I just spread a napkin over the files and eat what I'm gonna eat. Like a career bank robber-- you get too bold, you mess up, you're done. Today I spilled water on some guy's MRI results. Not doing that anymore. At least it wasn't something that stained. Just brush it off, and whistle my way along...

There's a character in the book, a helicopter pilot, who quotes a quote: "George Bernard Shaw, I think, said if you were not a communist at seventeen-- you had no heart. If you were a communist at forty-- you had no brains." According to google, the pilot is at least close in his quotation. 

The book goes on to tell how Israel keeps getting the shaft. The book is mostly strict nonfiction, except where names and timelines are concerned. It's one-sided, sure, but that one veiwpoint makes for some good stories. Like that of the two Israeli flying aces, the Walrus and the Carpenter. They can't, for the sake of international relations, shoot down the brand-new Russian MIG (and Russian pilot) that is patrolling over Israel on behalf of Israel's neighbors. So instead, they have to fly him into the ground. Draw him into a low-altitude chase, use the terrain, and trick him into crashing, Hollywood-style. Oh-- and the planes the Israelis were flying were obsolete training aircraft. Israel didn't have much else, it seems, thirty years ago. Fun times.  

"Zanek!" seems to mean "GO!" or "Jump!". 

I'm learnin me some stuff.

I hate ties, because they're totally non-functional. If I did some research, I bet I'd find that the fashion ancestor of the men's tie used to have some function, like keeping a shirt on, or a collar up, or something, but I don't want to do research. I just wanna rant. I hate having to wear ties. I feel silly. And they're restricting. I REALLY hope I can get away with not wearing one at work. Oh yeah, I'm working at a law office as a writer, basically doing the attorneys' dirty work, it's my first "real" job, I'm starting Friday, wheee. Ok, back to ties. I've got lots of them that have been given to me over the years. Never bought one. Ties are purely for fashion's sake, purely for display, and I'm not big on display. I'm big on content. I mean, if you're trying to look good, and you're wearing a nice shirt, at LEAST the shirt has a function besides looks... it keeps the wind off your back and stuff. The tie has no such merit. Like, if you're trying to be a phony (god, I sound all Holden Caulfield and high school and shit...), you'll wear a tie. If you're trying to take advantage of the fact that people often judge books by their covers, which is a dumb thing that people like to do, you'll wear a tie. In conclusion, and therefore and hereby and furthermore and all that shit, I hate ties. And I've got lots of them. The end. 

---------------------------------------------------------

Hokay. So. I want to get some people together for a game of four-way drunken chess. Who's in? 

WAIT! Hear me out... 


I have a four-way chess board (that Cecily gave me, cause she's awesome), and it would be cool to get anywhere from four to eight people together for a game. I'm thinking some setup like, you have to take a half shot every time one of your pieces dies. You'll start with 16 pieces, so a full shot per piece would be a little much... do the math... we might even have to tweak the amount of hooch per piece, depending on the alcohol tolerance of the people playing. A SOBER game of four-way chess might take three hours or more. I'm a fan of throwing lots of munchies in the mix. (These details are for those of you keen on figuring one's hypothetical BAC after this little adventure in strategery.) 

ANYWAYS if more people than four want to play, we could easily make teams of two, each team controlling one side of the board, either collaborating on moves, or (better, I think,) alternating turns. 

So we can work out the details and rules later, but the bottom line is the more pieces you lose, the more you drink, and you'll be trying to finish this game while smashed. Good times. 

BY THE WAY I see no reason why we couldn't teach someone to play who doesn't know how, so not knowing the game is no excuse for not coming. With the exception of my occasional moments of brilliance, I SUCK at chess. But it's still fun. So if you suck at chess too, that's also no excuse for not coming. Or- do you think you're good at chess? Let's see how good you are after six drinks... 

The most likely location would be my living room in Riverside. I'll pick a date after I get a feel for who wants to do this. Feel free to suggest dates and times. 


Uuber geeky? OH YEAH. 


Holla back, would you?

So I went "off-roading" on Monday, with Liz and Anne in the back of my jeep. It wasn't real off-roading, it was just us bouncing along some bumpy dirt roads, up hill and down dale. Good times. I've got my jeep stuck in the dirt before, way more easily than I thought it could get stuck, so I was paranoid. We were on the top of this one hill, and before driving down the trail I got out and looked over our obstacles, thinking, "ok, I have to get my tires between these two rocks, and to the outside of that big hole there, and the right tires can go over the top of that rock there, and..." And then I looked back at the jeep to see how much ground clearance I had, compared to what I'd be driving over. I walked back and announced to my fellow adventurers, "my official conclusion is, 'just fucking do it'". I was making the descent way more complicated than it had to be. So we just fucking did it, and down the hill we went, bouncy bouncy, and everything was lovely lovely, and now my car is dirty dirty. But there's a Karate Club car wash on Sunday, where I might take care of that problem. Squeaky squeaky.

A professor of mine once felt it necessary to point out the obvious to his class-- that certain aspects of the college lifestyle are no longer socially acceptable after you graduate. Like binge drinking, or living below the poverty line. Like rolling out of bed and going through your daily business unkept, in your pajamas, cause, like, who am I trying to impress? Like keeping a couch by the fire pit you dug in your backyard. 

On "Queer Eye for the Straight Guy", the Fab Five often accused guys of being "stuck in college", still keeping their living spaces looking like college pads at the ages of 25 or 30. That's one thing that pissed me off about that show. There is a spartan practicality, a logic to the college lifestyle that is admirable. College is the last bastion of adolescent contempt for the "adult" world. You get wrapped up in that world, you buy in. You forget the things you used to "know". 

If you're so wrapped up in something that you can't look at it objectively, weigh its qualities and faults, judge it from an outsider's point of view, then your judgment is a bit impaired, isn't it? 

Getting smashed once in a while has a similar, but shorter-lived, effect.

So? Let's not forget.

I graduated this morning. 

Tonight, in celebration, I ran. 

...

..

I'm going to hurt tomorrow.

I just came home from this little party out here in Riverside, and the girl hosting the party had a lot of friends who were in high school. They (the high school kids) needed an extra person to even out the teams in a game of guess-the-word-thingamajigger or whatever it was called. One guy was trying to get our team to guess the word "Cinderella", and he said something like, "Ummm... old Disney movie... think of the saying, 'If the shoe fits, wear it'..." And I answered right immediately. "Yes! Score one for the old guy!" he said. "Um, no offense, dude..."

FUCK you guys and your hard questions! (*Mwahahaha*) Let's see if y'all are good guessers:

Take My Quiz

QuizYourFriends.com!

"Kiss Me, I'm Shitfaced" by Dropkick Murphy isn't a fun song for me anymore. When I listen to it, it makes me sad. But I still listen. When the CD gets to that point, I just let it play. And I still know all the words. 

No comments, please.
